Algoriphagus boritolerans is a Gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacterium. It exhibits a rod-shaped morphology and is typically 0.5-0.8 μm wide and 1.0-3.0 μm long.

The species is able to grow at a wide range of temperatures, from 10°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 30°C. It is capable of tolerating moderate levels of salt (up to 4% NaCl) and can grow at a pH range of 6.0 to 8.0, with an optimal pH around 7.0.

Algoriphagus boritolerans is known to be able to degrade various polysaccharides, such as agar, alginate, and cellulose, and can utilize a variety of carbon sources for energy and growth. It has been reported to possess the ability to produce carotenoid pigments, which may contribute to its yellowish-orange colony appearance.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Algoriphagus boritolerans is closely related to other species within the genus Algoriphagus, which are typically found in a range of aquatic and soil environments.
